references.bibtex:
@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable formallowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

references.bibtex:
@inproceedings{10.5555/2283516.2283536,
author = {Darwiche, Adnan},
title = {SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases},
year = {2011},
isbn = {9781577355144},
publisher = {AAAI Press},
abstract = {We identify a new representation of propositional knowledge bases, the Sentential Decision Diagram (SDD), which is interesting for a number of reasons. First, it is canonical in the presence of additional properties that resemble reduction rules of OBDDs. Second, SDDs can be combined using any Boolean operator in polytime. Third, CNFs with n variables and treewidth w have canonical SDDs of size O(n2w), which is tighter than the bound on OBDDs based on pathwidth. Finally, every OBDD is an SDD. Hence, working with the latter does not preclude the former.},
booktitle = {Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two},
pages = {819826},
numpages = {8},
location = {Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain},
series = {IJCAI'11}
}
references.title: A. Darwiche, "SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases," Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two, pp. 819826, 2011.

references.bibtex: @article{Van den Broeck_Darwiche_2015, title={On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation}, volume={29}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/9423}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v29i1.9423}, abstractNote={ <p> Knowledge compilation is a powerful reasoning paradigm with many applications across AI and computer science more broadly. We consider the problem of bottom-up compilation of knowledge bases, which is usually predicated on the existence of a polytime function for combining compilations using Boolean operators (usually called an Apply function). While such a polytime Apply function is known to exist for certain languages (e.g., OBDDs) and not exist for others (e.g., DNNFs), its existence for certain languages remains unknown. Among the latter is the recently introduced language of Sentential Decision Diagrams (SDDs): while a polytime Apply function exists for SDDs, it was unknown whether such a function exists for the important subset of compressed SDDs which are canonical. We resolve this open question in this paper and consider some of its theoretical and practical implications. Some of the findings we report question the common wisdom on the relationship between bottom-up compilation, language canonicity and the complexity of the Apply function. </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Van den Broeck, Guy and Darwiche, Adnan}, year={2015}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: G. Van den Broeck and A. Darwiche, "On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 29, 2015.

references.bibtex: @article{Bova_2016, title={SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs}, volume={30}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/10107}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v30i1.10107}, abstractNote={ <p> Introduced by Darwiche (2011), sentential decision diagrams (SDDs) are essentially as tractable as ordered binary decision diagrams (OBDDs), but tend to be more succinct in practice. This makes SDDs a prominent representation language, with many applications in artificial intelligence and knowledge compilation. We prove that SDDs are more succinct than OBDDs also in theory, by constructing a family of boolean functions where each member has polynomial SDD size but exponential OBDD size. This exponential separation improves a quasipolynomial separation recently established by Razgon (2014), and settles an open problem in knowledge compilation (Darwiche, 2011). </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Bova, Simone}, year={2016}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: S. Bova, "SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 30, 2016.

matrix.description: The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $d$-$DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $d$-$DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $d$-$DNNF$ clause.

d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $DNNF$ clause.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Wegener_1987,Darwiche_2002}.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

MODS transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

nOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
It is well-known that some $CNF$ formulas (i.e. $\neg PARITY_n=\neg\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicants.

SDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to SDD in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If CNF transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If CNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

$d$-$DNNF$s can polynomially represent the disjunction of two functions with conflicting variable orders, which forces $FBDD$s to grow exponentially to track the state of both orders within a single "read-once" path.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $d-DNNF$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

noPolyDescription.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If d-DNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If d-DNNF transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.

uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
Shown by Corollary 3.5 of \citet{Beame_2013}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. Suppose not; then $\forall\Lambda\in DNF$, $\exists$ an equivalent $\Lambda_*\in d$-$DNNF$ of polynomial size. Since we can now perform a polynomial-time clausal entailment check on all $CNF$ sentences, the polynomial hierarchy collapses.

Recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the (not necessarily disjoint) rewirings of the nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and a 1-edge. We note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$ gates are decomposable. Furthermore, $\vee$ gates are only introduced in the rewriting, so we obtain a $dec$-$DNNF$ in linear time.

Consider the $DNF$ formula $\Pi_n= igvee_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicants form and each clause in $\Pi_n$ is an essential prime implicant of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Pi_n\in IP$.

Since the early work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicates of a formula is a lower bound on the number of clauses that can be found in any $CNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, $
eg\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, so any $CNF$ representation of $
eg\Pi_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}	o\{0,1\}$ so $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=0 \iff I 	ext{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. This is the negation of the clique detection function. However, it can be shown that $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates, which implies that not every $IP$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $IP$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable, so we attain a $DNNF$.

Consider the Boolean functions $\psi_n,\phi_n:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ that respectively test whether, in an $n \times n$ Boolean matrix, either the number of 1's is odd and there is a full row of 1's, or the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. An $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may simulate either $\psi_n$ or $\phi_n$, and thus the $uFBDD$ $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is of size $O(n^2)$; however, an $FBDD$ for $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is provably of size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If nOBDD transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$.

Any $DNF$ can be represented as an $nOBDD$ in linear time; however the family of $DNF$s $(\phi_n)_{n\in\N}$ built from expander graphs have treewidth linear in their size. Thus, any $uOBDD$ for $\phi_n$ is of size $2^{\Omega(|\phi_n|)}$.

d-SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If nOBDD transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If nOBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.
$PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$ has linear size $OBDD_<$ representations but only exponential size $CNF$ representations.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-SDNNF.

Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to DNNF.

MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD$_<$ transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to nFBDD.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD$_<$ transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to SDNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to uFBDD.

As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD_<$ is a subset of $OBDD$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to dec-DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to dec-SDNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $PI$ is a subset of $CNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is listed as an open problem in A Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. This is the clique detection function. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. However, it can be shown that $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants, and hence not every $PI$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If PI transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $PI$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

$SDD$ is a strict subset of $d$-$SDNNF$.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. If SDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

If SDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nFBDD.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nOBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to SDNNF.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that SDD cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bryant_1986,Bova_2016_a}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a structured $DNNF$ is a triple of the corresponding $DNNF$, the v-tree $T$, and a mapping $\rho$; as such, extracting a $DNNF$ from a $SDNNF$ is trivial.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to nFBDD.

This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If SDNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable; furthermore, all $\vee$-gates in the rewiring are deterministic, so we attain a $d$-$DNNF$.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uFBDD to DNNF.

Consider the Boolean functions $\phi_n, \psi_n: \{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$, which respectively test whether, in an $n\times n$ Boolean matrix, that the number of 1's is odd and there is a row full of 1's, and that the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. \citet{Bova_2016} and \citet{Wegener_2000} show that an $FBDD$ expression for $\phi_n \vee \psi_n$ has necessarily size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$; but since an $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may test $\phi_n$ or $\psi_n$ separately (shown by Proposition 3.1 of \citet{Amarilli_2018}), a $uFBDD$ for $\phi_n\vee \psi_n$ may be obtained by simply adding an $\vee$-gate joining these two $FBDD$ expressions, since $\phi_n \wedge \psi_n$ is unsatisfiable.

This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters," $uOBDD$ is the subset of $nOBDD$ satisfying unambiguity.

This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

$uOBDD$ can have polynomial size for $HWB_n$, but $OBDD$s have size $2^\Omega(n)$

If uOBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-DNNF.

Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to DNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD$ is a superset of $FBDD$. Therefore a polynomial time transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to nFBDD.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. The function $\bigwedge_{i=1}^n(x_i\Leftrightarrow y_i)$ has an $OBDD_<$ representation of size polynomial in $n$ whenever $<$ satisfies $x_1<y_1<...<x_n<y_n$ but exponential in $n$ if $<$ satisfies $x_1<x_2<...<x_n<y_1<y_2<...<y_n$

Every $OBDD$ is a right-linear $SDD$; $SDD$ generalizes $OBDD$.

OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to uFBDD.
As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters," $OBDD$ is the subset of $uOBDD$ without any $\vee$-node.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to dec-DNNF.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.  In the case of an OBDD, all disjunctions in the resulting circuit arise from the rewriting of decision nodes, so every $\vee$-gate is a decision gate. Combined with the structured decomposability ensured by the $v$-tree, this yields a dec-SDNNF. The translation is linear in the size of $D$.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to d-DNNF.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $dec$-$SDNNF$ is the subset of $d$-$SDNNF$ satisfying the decision property, so transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to DNNF.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $dec$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $dec$-$DNNF$, so discarding the v-tree completes the transformation.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where given each pair $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one of must be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where after pairing $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one pair must have both be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$.
